name: Guest
description:
Why: The user has not committed yet and is only browsing after arriving from ads, organic search, blog, or referral. Bad guests mean low‑quality signups; good guests mean higher activation with less traffic.
Team focus: Clear message, sharp CTA, remove distractions. This is not a sales moment; it is an invitation moment.

name: Registered – Not Verified
description:
Why: Early friction. The user registered but did not verify email/phone, so they are not yet a “real” user. Drop‑off here signals low trust or a painful flow.
Team focus: Simplify verification, explain why verification matters. UX and trust matter more than features here.

name: Registered – No Resume
description:
Why: Activation lag. The account exists but no resume has been started. Curiosity is present, but the user is stuck.
Team focus: Drive the first action fast, remove extra choices. Push, do not teach.

name: Started Resume – Incomplete
description:
Why: The resume was started but abandoned. The user saw value but hit friction (complexity, fatigue, uncertainty). This is the biggest product drop‑off.
Team focus: Reduce friction, smart reminders, break the flow into smaller steps. Design beats sales here.

name: Free – First Resume Completed
description:
Why: The first resume is completed; this is the real activation moment and the true entry point to the product.
Team focus: Celebrate success and show “what’s next.” This is still trust‑building, not selling.

name: Free – Activated (Exploring)
description:
Why: The user is mentally ready for more value but has not decided to pay.
Team focus: Gradually introduce capabilities and show the growth path. Product story matters more than price. Offer light nudges (e.g., interview questions or position suggestions) without pressure.

name: Free – Feature Blocked
description:
Why: The golden sales moment—hit a locked feature and felt the pain.
Team focus: Explain the benefit clearly and connect the feature to the user’s problem. Sales should resolve pain, not advertise.

name: Paid – Just Converted
description:
Why: Prevent buyer’s remorse. The user just paid and is still judging the decision.
Team focus: Lead them to their first paid win fast and remove ambiguity. Speed beats features here.

name: Paid – Active
description:
Why: They are using what they paid for, often across multiple resumes.
Team focus: Reinforce regular usage and show ROI. Consistency is key.

name: Paid – Power User
description:
Why: Highest LTV. Uses advanced tools like Interview and Skill Gap.
Team focus: Give special attention and collect feedback. These users are product partners, not just customers.

name: Paid – Credit Exhausted
description:
Why: Wants to continue but has no credits; an active user who hit the limit.
Team focus: This user is ready to buy now—be transparent, offer usage‑matched options, and do clean upsell without pressure. Fair and logical sales only.

name: Paid – Expired Plan
description:
Why: A former paying user whose plan expired (time/system event). They paid before and can return.
Team focus: Remind them of past value and the reason to come back. Value nostalgia works here.

name: Payment Failed
description:
Why: They tried to pay but it failed; bad experience can cause fast churn.
Team focus: Human error messaging and fast resolution. Support beats product here.

name: Dormant User
description:
Why: No activity for a while. Could be free or paid, with or without credits. Reactivation is cheaper than acquisition.
Team focus: Bring them back with smart reminders and new value, non‑intrusive messaging. Give a reason to return, not empty notifications. Soft re‑engagement.

name: Churn-risk User
description:
Why: Still around but usage is declining—prevention before the drop.
Team focus: Early detection and proactive intervention. Prediction beats treatment here.
